Graphical abstract Highlights ► Deactivation of Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts were studied under tail end conditions of C2H2 hydrogenation. ► The catalyst with the highest long-term stability contains the lowest Ag amount. ► Catalyst regeneration must include a H2 treatment. The selective hydrogenation of acetylene is one process to remove traces of acetylene from steam cracker cuts during the production of ethylene. Current disadvantages of commercially used Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts applied in the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation are relative short cycle time (fast deactivation) caused by green oil formation and deposition of coke. Long-term tests were performed in a laboratory reactor under typical industrial conditions to investigate the deactivation of those catalysts. It was found that the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalyst with the highest long-term stability contains a Ag/Pd-ratio in the bulk of 0.41 and the lowest concentration of silver. This low silver amount causes a higher dilution of the palladium surface area than the higher silver amount within the investigated catalysts. This was indicated by CO chemisorption experiments, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron probe micro analysis (EPMA), X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and through the investigation of hydrocarbons deposited on the catalyst surface. The same catalyst sample was subsequently regenerated and tested in the laboratory reactor with respect to its long-term stability. The regenerated samples have the same long-term stability as the fresh sample if the regeneration procedure includes a hydrogen treatment. Keywords Acetylene hydrogenation Ethylene Palladium Silver Alumina Egg shell catalyst CO chemisorption TEM EPMA XPS 1 Introduction Ethylene is mainly produced by steam cracking of naphtha [1]. This cracking process produces also impurities, e.g., acetylene that causes an irreversible damage of the catalysts used in downstream processes of the steam cracker (for example Ziegler–Natta catalysts in the polymerization of ethylene). The acetylene content has to be reduced to concentrations lower that 1ppmv to avoid this damage [2]. The removal of acetylene is carried out by selective hydrogenation to ethylene. Thereby an ethylene gain of the steam cracker is achievable which has additional economic value [3]. The amount of this ethylene gain is linked with the selectivity of the acetylene hydrogenation catalyst. Therefore a targeted improvement of the hydrogenation catalyst is one possibility to increase the ethylene selectivity. This catalyst should have high long-term stability, in other words a low loss of activity and selectivity during their cycle time. Furthermore the catalyst has to be regenerable so that it can to be used in several cycles during its lifetime. Originally nickel, iron and cobalt containing catalysts were used in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene but sulfur compounds had to be added to minimize ethylene losses. The undesired polymerization of acetylene resulting in an agglomeration of the catalyst necessitated regenerations quite often [4]. In the 1950s Bond et al. [5] proved palladium to be the most active and selective metal in the hydrogenation of acetylene. About 20 years later a new catalyst type was commercially used containing 0.04wt.% palladium impregnated on Al2O3-pellets [4]. Another ten years later bimetallic catalyst systems and especially Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts were established in the industry and are still used by today [6,7]. These catalysts are characterized by an egg shell distribution of palladium and silver over the catalyst pellet to reduce the influence of mass transfer resistance [8]. Other catalyst systems than palladium containing catalysts were also investigated in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene such as Rh [5], Pt [5,9], Ir [10], Au [11,12], Fe [13], Cu [14], Ni–S [15], Ni–Cu [16] and Ni–Sn [17]. One of the latest investigations of non precious metal catalyst dealt with Ni–Zn because of the lower manufacturing price compared to precious metal containing catalysts [18,19]. Ni–Zn impregnated on MgO/Al2O3 gave a higher selectivity to ethylene than a Pd–Ag catalyst. Many researchers followed the concept of promoting palladium, which was reviewed by Borodzinski and Bond [20]. Some examples of such promoters are Si [21,22], Ag [23–27], Ti [28,29], Cu [30,31], Th [32], Au [33–37], Pb [38,39], Co [40], Ni [41,42], K [43,44], Ce [45], Nb [45], Re [46] and Zn [47]. Shin et al. [21] carried out IR spectroscopy respectively, XPS measurements and proved the ensemble effect on Pd–Si-catalysts. A partially covering of the palladium surface area by silicon was found in these investigations while a change of the electronic properties could not be observed. The ensemble effect was also found on Pd–Ag/Al2O3-catalyst but additionally the ligand effect was verified by XRD and XPS measurements [23]. The ensemble effect describes the dilution of the Pd-surface area of the Pd/Al2O3-catalyst by silver, which causes the formation of Pd-islands and single Pd-surface atoms [48]. By means of that the ability of the catalyst to chemisorb hydrogen (dissociatively) is diminished because the decoration of the Pd-surface area by silver reduces the number of neighbored Pd-atoms [23]. Furthermore the undesired formation of by-products like green oil, coke and ethane is decelerated [49]. In contrast to that the ligand effect represents the electronic modification of the Pd/Al2O3-catalyst by silver addition [23]. In this context a charge transfer is understood resulting in a decrease of unfilled Pd 3d-states [25] but different opinions about the mechanism were discussed in the past. Some authors [50,51] reported about a decreasing number of d-holes on palladium as well as on silver. Simultaneously non-d-electrons disappeared on both metals too that indicated an internal charge transfer within the same atom. Other studies [24,25,52] proved that an external charge transfer from a silver atom to a palladium atom took place. Recently, intermetallic Pd–Ga compounds were studied [53–60]. According to the authors the active site isolation of palladium by gallium resulted in a more selective catalyst as Pd/Al2O3. The development of a new catalyst type was carried out by the preparation of Pd nanoparticles and their stabilization by an ionic liquid [61]. Very high selectivities to ethylene in the range of 80–85% were observed during a test within a laboratory reactor at acetylene conversions of about 10%. The catalysts investigated in this article are used in a process called C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation. A requirement of this process is the separation of the C2 hydrocarbons acetylene, ethylene and ethane from the cracked gas of the steam cracker. As described by Borodzinski and Bond [62], the necessary hydrogen for the removal of acetylene has to be added into the reactor where the following four reactions take place: (1) C2H2 +H2 →C2H4 (2) C2H4 +H2 →C2H6 (3) 2C2H2 +2H2 →C4H8 (4) nC2H2 + mH2 →greenoilandcoke Reaction (1) is the desired reaction whereby acetylene is selectively hydrogenated to ethylene. Simultaneously ethylene is hydrogenated to ethane in reaction (2), which leads to an unwanted reduction of the ethylene selectivity of the process. Furthermore acetylene is, as shown in reaction (3), hydrooligomerized to butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene). Moreover the formation of heavy hydrocarbons from acetylene and hydrogen is illustrated in reaction (4). The reactions (2)–(4) should be prevented to obtain high selectivities to ethylene. Butadiene is proposed to be involved in this formation of heavy hydrocarbons [63]. These heavy hydrocarbons are composed of liquid and solid parts. The liquid part is usually called “green oil” which is predominately consisting of olefins and paraffins but also to a minor extent of diolefins and aromatics [63,64]. Green oil is generally accepted as the precursor for the solid coke. The coke is deposited on the active sites of the catalyst leading to an activity decrease [65]. Therefore several regenerations have to be carried out during the lifetime of the catalyst. But the coke depositions cause also a positive effect. Stationary conditions of the acetylene hydrogenation are reached only after some coke has been built up on the catalyst surface [66]. First this coke is present as subsurface carbon in the octahedral lattice of the palladium crystallites. This subsurface carbon suppresses the formation of subsurface hydrogen and palladium hydride species responsible for the total hydrogenation of alkynes [53,54]. Though this positive effect turns again into a negative effect after some coke layers have been formed. Then the diffusion of hydrogen into the palladium bulk is accelerated resulting in an undesired high activity of the hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane [67]. There is also another reaction path for a favored hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane. Hydrogen is activated on palladium, transferred to the support over the coke depositions (spillover) and converted with ethylene to ethane [30,64,68–71]. This spillover effect can be minimized by promoting Pd with Cu, Sn and Au [72] or Ag [23]. The objective of this article is to determine the properties of Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalyst pellets as fresh, used and regenerated samples in terms of dispersion, metal loading and metal distribution over the pellet, formation of alloys as well as long-term stability. Conclusions will be drawn from these properties for the development of an improved catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Five catalysts (A, B, C, D and E) were prepared by incipient wetness of an Al2O3-support with aqueous palladium and/or silver salt solutions. Then an after-treatment was carried out. More details cannot be given because the preparation methods of these catalysts are just filed for patents but have not yet been granted. The catalysts A, B and C are palladium and silver containing catalysts. The samples D and E are the silver and the palladium free versions of catalyst C and will be used as reference samples. The properties of these catalysts are given in Table 1 and measured with the methods described in the next chapters. 2.2 Chemical composition The metal content of the catalysts was measured by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF). Prior the samples were heated up to 800°C in air, held for 2h and ground with a mill (Shatterbox 8515) to an average particle diameter of 10μm. Then 8g of the samples were blended with 2g of the binder polyethylene (Ceridust 130, Clariant) and compacted into pills by a press (PAL-P40-M, PFAFF). These pills were 6mm in height and 40mm in diameter. They were investigated with the XRF-spectrometer “S4 Explorer” (Bruker AXS) by using a wave-dispersive X-ray detector (WDX). The palladium and silver contents were determined with a calibrated method. 2.3 Dispersion of the active metal 2.3.1 Impulse chemisorption of CO The catalyst samples were pretreated in a glass reactor with a flow of 3l/h hydrogen and 200°C for 1h. Then the reactor was connected to the chemisorption apparatus (TPD/R/O 1100, Themo Finnigan) and cooled down to 0°C in a 30ml/min flow of hydrogen (H2 5.0, Linde AG). At the beginning of the measurement a pulse of 0.335ml CO (CO 4.7, Linde AG) was introduced in the glass reactor which was repeated every 5min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) recorded the CO-signals, which were lowered as CO was chemisorbed on the sample. If the sample takes up the maximum amount of CO, then all following signals will have the same peak area. Therefore the decrease of the signal area corresponds with the CO content n CO chemisorbed on the sample. CO is chemisorbed on palladium only and not on silver. The average crystallite size of Pd-catalysts d ¯ Pd , CO was determined by: d ¯ Pd , CO = 5 S Pd ρ Pd Therein ρ Pd is the density of palladium and S Pd the specific palladium surface area. The factor 5 is a result of the facts that palladium crystallizes in the face centered cubic lattice (fcc) and one of the six areas of the cube is covered by the catalyst support. It is not appropriate to determine the average size of Pd–Ag crystallites by the last two equations because silver covers the palladium surface area partially and is not chemisorbing CO. Due to those two effects the amount of CO chemisorbed on Pd/Ag catalysts is lower than on Pd catalyst with the same palladium content. The average crystallite sizes of all catalysts were also determined by using a transmission electron microscopy and are indicated in Table 1 as d ¯ Pd , TEM or d ¯ Pd – Ag , TEM . 2.3.2 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The determination of the average crystallite sizes was carried by using a TEM (JEM-3010, JEOL) with an acceleration voltage of 300kV. The active shell of the catalysts was rubbed off by 2min milling (SM 2000, Retsch). The powder was ground, dispersed in methanol and treated in an ultrasonic bath. Afterwards the dispersion rested therewith big particles were settled out. Then the dispersion was dropped onto a carbon supported copper grid, which was transferred into the microscope after the methanol was totally evaporated. Several TEM-pictures of the catalysts A, B, C and D were taken from the bright field by the digital camera “GATAN” equipped with a CCD sensor (resolution 0.17nm). The crystallites were sized and counted. The mean crystallite sizes including the standard deviations are given in Table 1. Representative pictures of the catalysts A, B, C and D are shown in Fig. 1 . An important property of the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts is the grade of dilution GD of the palladium surface area by silver which was calculated by the following equation under usage of the measured CO chemisorption n CO and theoretical CO chemisorption n CO,TEM: G D = 1 − n CO n CO , TEM 100 % The theoretical CO chemisorption, n CO,TEM was calculated from the results of the TEM analyses by using the Pd-mole ratio within the catalyst g Pd, the Avogadro constant N A and the space requirement for one Pd-atom a Pd: n CO , TEM = 5 g Pd d ¯ Pd – Ag , TEM ρ Pd N A a Pd One requirement of this approach is the presence of comparable average palladium crystallites sizes determined with CO chemisorption and TEM measurements of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst D, which was the case in this work with 4.2nm and 4.4nm, respectively. The grade of dilution GD of the catalysts A, B and C are shown in Table 2 . It was found that the grade of dilution of the palladium in catalyst C is markedly higher than in catalysts A and B. 2.4 Surface area The surface area of the catalysts was determined by using the BET method [73]. The samples were ground to a diameter from 0.8 to 1.4mm and heated up to 300°C in nitrogen to remove water and other adsorbed compounds. Then 0.5g of the sample were filled in a reaction vessel and connected with the measure device (Gemini 2360, Micromeretics). Gaseous nitrogen was added into the vessel after cooling down to −194°C in a Dewar filled with liquid nitrogen and evacuation to 3−5 bar. Afterwards the pressure drop was measured at five points between 50 and 200mbar. The pressure drop corresponds with the adsorbed nitrogen, which was used to determine die BET surface area from the slope of BET equation. 2.5 Metal and carbon distribution The analysis of the metal distributions was performed with electron probe micro analyses (EPMA) by using an electron microscope (SEMQ, ARL). The cylindrical catalyst pellets were polished on the top surface whereby the catalytic active Pd-egg shell was revealed. Afterwards the pellets were covered with a carbon layer to increase the thermal conductivity and then transferred into the microscope. The measurements were carried out under high vacuum (10−7 bar) and with an electron beam having an acceleration voltage of 25kV. A WDX detector was used for recording the signals. Representative metal distributions of the catalysts A, B, C and D are shown in Fig. 2 . The depth of the Pd-layer is read out from those pictures. This depth is at same time the average breadth of the catalytic active zone δ ¯ , which is given in Table 1. The carbon profile was determined with the same equipment. The sample was pretreated in a 3l/h nitrogen flow at 200°C for 2h to remove liquid hydrocarbon depositions, which would damage the microscope irreversibly during the measurement. The signals were detected with an energy-dispersive X-ray detector (EDX). Moreover the sample was not covered with carbon. 2.6 Alloy formation An alloy formation between palladium and silver was validated by X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Three catalyst pellets were placed next to each other on the sample holder of the spectrometer (LHS12, Leybold). After evacuation to 10−4 bar and reduction at 100°C the samples were transferred into the measurement chamber where a vacuum of 10−13 mbar was placed. The electrons near the core level of the metals were dissolved by the X-ray beam with a photon energy E ph =1.3keV which originated from a Mg Kα-source of radiation. The kinetic energy E kin of the dissolved electrons was measured by the analyzer “EA11/100” equipped with an electron multiplier. The electron binding energies E b of palladium and silver were calculated from the kinetic energy by using the Einstein equation: E ph = E kin + E b + Φ The work function of the spectrometer Φ is determined by reference measurements. The palladium and silver electron binding energies E b of the five catalysts are given in Table 3 . This table also contains reference binding energies of metallic respectively, oxidic palladium as well as silver [74]. Before a measurement took place the XPS apparatus was calibrated against the Al2O3-support of the catalysts considering energy shifts caused by electric charging of the catalyst surface. Additionally the metal concentration at the catalyst surface was measured by integration of the X-ray photoelectron spectra. The results measured with catalysts A, B and C are given in Table 4 . Therein the silver/palladium ratio on the crystallite surface area (Ag/Pd)s is compared with the ratio of the two metals in the bulk of the crystallite (Ag/Pd)b. The latter value was calculated with the metal contents in Table 1 determined with XRF. 2.7 Catalysis experiments The catalytic measurements were performed in the test rig outlined in Fig. 3 . The experimental reactor was an integral fixed bed reactor, which is shown schematically in Fig. 4 . This reactor was made of stainless steel S316 and had an internal diameter of 25.5mm, a wall thickness of 12.75mm diameter and a length of 300mm. A thermocouple well was placed in the center of the reactor tube and measured eight temperatures along the catalyst bed. A catalyst volume of 15ml catalyst was divided in five parts, diluted with 85ml α-Al2O3 spheres (diameter 2mm, Sasol) and placed near the temperature measurements. The temperature of the reactor could be adjusted between 20 and 100°C by a heating jacket and a chiller (Julabo F25) filled with water–ethylene glycol-mixture. The test gas (Linde AG) was stored in a gas bundle consisting of 12 cylinders with a total volume of 0.48m3 and a pressure of 100bar. A continuous gas flow of 60l/h was realized by a mass flow controller (Bronkhorst). The pressure of the reactor was set to 10bar by a pressure controller. The test gas contained 1vol.% of acetylene, 1.4vol.% of hydrogen, 30vol.% of ethylene, 66.6vol.% of argon and 1vol.% of propane. The latter was used as an internal standard for the gas chromatography. The composition of the reactor outlet gas stream was analyzed by a GC (Agilent 6890) equipped with a capillary column (HP-PLOT, Al2O3-“S”-deactivated) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The FID detected only the GC-signals of the hydrocarbons, which were integrated by the software “Chemstation”. The signals were converted into mol concentrations x i by using 100% standardization as well as correction factors [75]. The argon concentration was kept constant. The hydrogen concentration was calculated from the hydrocarbon conversions. Upfront every catalytic test, the catalysts were reduced in situ at 100°C for 1h in a flow of 10l/h hydrogen (purity 5.0, Linde AG) realized by a mass flow controller (Bronkhorst). The catalytic tests were carried out at an acetylene conversion of about 70% because this correlates with the acetylene conversion within the first catalyst bed of the industrial reactor where the fastest deactivation of the catalyst is taking place. The acetylene conversion in the experimental reactor was kept constant by adjusting the temperature of the reactor. The activity and the selectivity to ethylene were used to evaluate the deactivation behavior of the catalysts. The acetylene conversion was calculated by: X C 2 H 2 = 1 − x C 2 H 2 x C 2 H 2 0 100 % The selectivity to ethylene was determined with the following equation by using the concentrations of acetylene, ethane and the butenes because changes of the ethylene concentration cannot be tracked exactly [58]: S C 2 H 4 = 1 − ( x C 2 H 6 − x C 2 H 6 0 ) − 2 ( x C 4 H 8 − x C 4 H 8 0 ) x C 2 H 2 0 − x C 2 H 2 100 % Due to the thermal gradient in the laboratory reactor was low (maximal 5°C) the catalyst activity was evaluated with the arithmetic average temperature T ¯ determined by using the temperatures within the five catalyst layers: T ¯ = T 4 + T 5 + T 6 + T 7 + T 8 5 2.8 Properties of used catalysts At the end of every deactivation test the used catalyst was investigated in view of hydrocarbon depositions with a carbon analyzer (CS 800, ELTRA). After milling 1g of the samples were mixed with 1.5g wolfram and 0.5g iron to ensure complete carbon combustion in the induction furnace at 1500°C and under an oxygen flow of 180l/h. The concentration of the combustion product CO2 was measured by an infrared sensor. The concentration of the fixed carbon was determined after a pre-treatment of the sample in a 3l/h nitrogen flow at 300°C for 2h while the total amount of carbon was measured by using the untreated sample. Moreover TPD/O-measurements were carried out in a thermobalance (L81, Linseis) to investigate desorption and oxidation behavior of the used and the fresh catalysts. By carrying out these measurements different natures of the carbon depositions can be distinguished. Seventy to ninety milligram pounded catalyst were placed on a sample holder and transferred into the measurement chamber. After inertization for 1h hydrogen, nitrogen or air was introduced and the chamber was heated up from 20°C to 800°C in with a ramp of 5°C/min. The thermobalance works based on the zero-balance principle. The angle of the sample holder was changed as a result of the mass loss caused by the removal of hydrocarbon depositions. The change of the angle was compensated by two current coils. Therefore a change of the electric current corresponds with the mass loss of the catalyst. 2.9 Regeneration The deposition of hydrocarbons is the reason for the deactivation of the catalysts, which resulted in a decrease of the activity and selectivity to ethylene. These depositions can be removed by regeneration of the catalysts, which involves a treatment in air–steam mixtures up to 500°C [76,77]. Jin et al. [49] showed that a hydrogen after-treatment causes a higher selectivity to ethylene than without this after-treatment. For this reason several regenerations of the same catalyst sample were performed with nitrogen and/or hydrogen at different temperatures. The used catalyst was placed in a 75ml tubular quartz reactor (200mm in height and 20mm in diameter) between two layers of 10ml α-Al2O3-spheres (diameter 2mm, Sasol). The flows of nitrogen, hydrogen and air were adjusted by mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst). Steam was produced by flowing water into the quartz reactor with the help of a peristaltic pump (Gilson Minipuls 3) as 150°C was reached within the catalyst bed. After every regeneration procedure the deactivation behavior of the catalyst samples were investigated in the experimental reactor as described in Section 2.7. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Deactivation behavior of fresh catalysts The Ag/Pd-ratio of the catalysts A, B and C ranged from 0.41 up to 5.26 while the Pd-content was about 0.035wt.%. Other researchers [5,23–26,29,59,72,78] investigated catalysts showing a Ag/Pd-ratio from 0.11 [5] up to 7.69 [25] while the Pd-content varied between 0.03wt.% [25] and 4.5wt.% [5]. This means the catalysts A, B and C in this work have Ag/Pd-ratios and Pd-contents comparable to other studies. Short-term tests of about 60h were carried out with the catalysts A, B, C and D in the fixed bed reactor. The results of these investigations are shown as time-dependent graphs of the average reactor temperature and the selectivity to ethylene in Fig. 5 . It is obvious that the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts A, B and C are more stable than the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst D. The latter deactivated very fast because the temperature had to be increased after 40h to keep the acetylene conversion level at about 70%. The selectivity to ethylene was reduced since the beginning of this test and reached values in the range of 20% at the end. The sharp temperature increase and the fast drop of selectivity of catalyst D as well as the stable behavior of the catalysts A, B and C prove Pd–Ag/Al2O3 to be the better catalyst type for the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation. However, a test time of 60h is too short for a final ranking of the long-term stability of catalysts A, B and C. For this reason these catalysts were tested again within the fixed bed reactor up to 500h. The determined average temperatures and selectivities to ethylene are given in Fig. 6 . Thus differences of the long-term stability appeared not until 100h time on stream. The highest long-term stability was reached with catalyst C while the catalyst A performed second best and catalyst B showed the fastest deactivation. The best performance of catalyst C can be chiefly explained by the chemical composition and the dispersion of the catalysts. Catalyst C has the lowest silver concentration (0.015wt.%), a Ag/Pd-ratio in the bulk of 0.41 but also the lowest CO chemisorption (0.09μmol/gcat). This is not as expected. In general the CO chemisorption is rising with decreasing silver content which is indicated by the properties of the catalysts A, B and D in Table 1. That means the small silver amount within catalyst C is diluting the palladium surface area much more than the higher silver amount within the catalysts A and B. This conclusion is admissible because the CO chemisorption reflects the number of accessible palladium surface atoms and because the average crystallite sizes of the catalysts A, B and C are comparable. This dilution of the palladium surface area can be numerically described by the grade of dilution (GD) in Table 2. This value is higher for catalyst C (83%) than for catalyst A and B (35% and 11%). The dilution of the palladium surface area is assumed to be the result of the partial replacement of palladium surface atoms by silver. Caused by the partial replaced palladium surface atoms, the number of neighbored palladium surface atoms is reduced. Accordingly the number of dissociatively adsorbed acetylene molecules is lower resulting in the formation of green oil, coke and ethane (side products of the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation). Due to the lower green oil formation, fewer hydrocarbons are deposited on catalyst C (see Section 3.2) causing the hydrogenation activity of the palladium to remain longer. In other words, the increase of temperature was slower compared to the catalysts A and B. The higher selectivity to ethylene of catalyst C originates from the lower hydrocarbon depositions but also from the higher dilution of the palladium surface area. Hydrogen is to a lesser extent activated on palladium, transferred to the support by the spillover effect and converted with ethylene to ethane on the support. Additionally pore plugging within catalyst C is diminished because the formation of heavy hydrocarbons is reduced. Consequently, ethylene cannot be accumulated within these pores by diffusion resulting in a minimized ethane formation. The higher dilution of the palladium surface area of catalyst C is also confirmed by the comparison of the Ag/Pd-ratio on the catalyst surface (Ag/Pd)s with the Ag/Pd-ratio in the catalyst bulk (Ag/Pd)b in Table 4. A silver enrichment on the surface was only observed on catalyst C. The Ag/Pd-ratio increased from 0.41 in the bulk to 0.86 on the surface while a silver downgrade was found on the catalysts A and B. Therefore, the silver within the catalysts A and B is not only used for diluting the palladium surface area but also to form separate silver crystallites. This conclusion is consistent with the EPMA measurements because silver was also found across the catalyst pellet where palladium does not occur. In contrast, the EPMA analysis of catalyst C showed silver and palladium arise predominantly together on the catalyst pellet. Palladium and silver are present in the metallic forms during the XPS measurements indicated by the Pd 3d5/2 and Ag 3d5/2 electron binding energies in Table 3 which are always in the range of Pd0 respectively, Ag0. The electronic structure of these metals is the same during the catalytic tests and the XPS measurements because hydrogen pre-treatment at 100°C was carried out in both investigations. An ensemble effect between palladium and silver was found on catalyst C while the ligand effect was not observed. The ensemble effect causes reorganization of the palladium surface area on catalyst C resulting in a silver enrichment on the catalyst surface. An electronic or ligand effect between palladium and silver could not be observed on catalyst C because a shift of the electron binding energies of palladium and silver was not found on all Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts in this work. The reasons for that are either a ligand effect was not present or not detectable because of the low metal concentrations. However, Pd–Ag-alloys were observed in other studies by using the same catalyst system with higher metal concentrations and XRD-equipment [23,52,78]. Because of that we believe the ligand effect is present on the catalysts used in this work but is not detectable with XPS. In contrast to the literature, an ensemble effect was even not observable on catalyst A and B because the silver content is diminished on the catalyst surface compared to the bulk. An enrichment of the second metal was also found on the surface in the literature during XPS investigations of Pd–Ag, Pd–Cu and Pd–Au catalyst while a change of the electronic structure was not found and assumed to be of minor importance [23,52,72,78–81]. 3.2 Investigations of used catalysts After each test the catalysts were unloaded in three layers representing the upper, the middle and the lower catalyst layer within the experimental reactor. The catalyst pellets originating from the upper layer were used to measure the metal and carbon distribution over the catalyst pellet by using EPMA. A representative metal and carbon profile on catalyst C is shown in Fig. 7 . The carbon profile is comparable with the palladium distribution. Furthermore the maxima of palladium and carbon are almost at the same place. Consequently, it is assumed the formation of green oil and coke took place on palladium. Furthermore a change of the metal distribution during reaction and/or regeneration did not occur what can be seen by a comparison of the metal distributions of the fresh catalyst C in Fig. 2(c) and of the used catalyst C in Fig. 7. Every catalyst layer was investigated with regard to the total and the fixed carbon contents x C after the catalytic test of 60h and up to 500h. The carbon contents are given in Tables 5 and 6 . These tables also contain the test time t test and specific BET surface area related carbon deposition m ˙ C . This value was calculated with the following equation which was deduced in [82]: m ˙ C = ( x ¯ C d cat 2 ) / ( 1 − x ¯ C ) A BET [ 6 δ ¯ d cat 2 − 12 δ ¯ 2 d cat + 8 δ ¯ 3 ] t test The lowest carbon depositions m ˙ C were measured on catalyst C. The highest values are determined on catalyst B, which also deactivated the fastest. As a result, there is a direct relation between the deactivation of the catalyst and the carbon depositions. This theory is supported by the results of the 60h catalytic test. Catalyst D was deactivating the fastest during this tests and showed the highest carbon content after the catalytic test. TPO measurements with air were performed on the fresh catalysts and TPD/TPO investigations were carried out with air, nitrogen and hydrogen on the used samples from the catalytic tests up to 500h. Mass losses were detected on all samples. The results are summarized in Table 7 . It is obvious that the used catalysts cannot be cleaned completely from the hydrocarbon depositions by using nitrogen and hydrogen because the mass losses are higher after the air treatment. The mass losses are also presented in dependence on the temperature as derivative thermo gravimetric signals (DTG). The DTG signals in Fig. 8(a) are measured by using the fresh samples during the thermal treatment in air. The DTG signals in Fig. 8(b–d) were observed during a thermal treatment of the used catalysts in air, nitrogen and hydrogen. The DTG signals can be differentiated into four ranges: 1. Loss of humidity between 40 and 100°C. 2. Mobilization of light hydrocarbon depositions from 180 to 240°C. 3. Removal of heavy hydrocarbons between 330 and 370°C. 4. Burning off of fixed coke from 420 up to 520°C. A loss of humidity was observed during every thermal treatment. It is only possible to distinguish between light and heavy hydrocarbon depositions as well as fixed coke by looking at the different temperature ranges these compounds were removed. Light and heavy hydrocarbons could be removed by a thermal treatment in nitrogen, hydrogen or air. CO and CO2 were not detected during the treatments with hydrogen or nitrogen. That means oxygen traces in hydrogen, nitrogen or oxygen contained in the hydrocarbon depositions were not causing a burning off of the hydrocarbons. Fixed carbon could exclusively be removed by an air treatment or to be precisely by a reaction with the oxygen of the air to CO and CO2. The higher mass losses of catalyst A are a result of the three times higher hydrocarbon depositions compared to catalysts B and C. 3.3 Experiments with regenerated catalysts Catalyst C shows the best performance during the long-term tests and this catalyst can be recommended for industrial use in a C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor. For this reason regeneration experiments were only carried out with this catalyst. As shown in Table 8 the same catalyst sample was regenerated five times (see different steps from 5.1 to 5.5). During those regenerations different after treatments were performed with nitrogen and/or hydrogen at different temperatures. As given in Table 8 step 8 this catalyst sample was tested in the fixed bed reactor after every regenerative treatment. This means overall this sample was tested up to five times. The amount of hydrocarbon deposition m dep is also given in Table 8. These depositions were generated during the catalytic tests and determined by weighing the sample before and after the test. The catalyst weight after each regenerative treatment corresponds with the mass of the fresh catalyst, which points out the catalyst surface can be cleaned from the hydrocarbon depositions by a thermal treatment in steam–air-mixtures. The sample was investigated with regard to the carbon content after a 6th regeneration was carried out. Carbon was not detected on this sample. Therefore it was concluded that every regenerated catalyst sample was free of hydrocarbon depositions. The graphs of the temperature measured during the catalytic tests are not shown because the differences between the tests were low (3°C). The determined selectivities to ethylene are presented in Fig. 9 . If an after treatment in hydrogen follows at not less than 120°C then the long-term stability of the regenerated catalyst will be comparable to that of the fresh catalyst. Due to this after treatment the metal oxides are reduced to Pd0 respectively, Ag0. In case the hydrogen after treatment is not performed, the selectivity to ethylene is decreased faster (see 4th regeneration). If the catalyst is regenerated and retreated in hydrogen at 120°C then the long-term stability of the regenerated and the fresh sample will be comparable again (see 5th regeneration). For this reason, it is concluded catalyst C can be subsequently regenerated five times without an observable loss of long-term stability. 4 Conclusion It was shown that the catalyst system Pd–Ag/Al2O3 can be improved even though it is well established in the industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation for many years. The Pd–Ag/Al2O3-catalyst with the lowest silver content (Ag/Pd-ratio of 0.41) is characterized by the highest long-term stability with regard to activity and selectivity to ethylene compared with the other Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts in this work. The highest long-term stability is the result of the higher dilution of the palladium surface area by silver, a silver enrichment on the catalyst surface and lower coke deposition. This silver is exclusively used for diluting the palladium surface area while a silver downgrade and separate silver crystallites exist on other Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts. As a consequence the number of neighbored palladium surface atoms is reduced by the silver enrichment on the catalyst surface. Thus, the dissociative adsorption of acetylene molecules is diminished resulting in a lower formation of side products (green oil, coke and ethane). The active sites of the catalyst are blocked by green oil and coke leading to a reduced activity while the formation of ethane lowers the selectivity to ethylene. The activation of hydrogen is diminished by the higher diluted palladium surface area and the transfer of hydrogen is decelerated by the lower coke depositions on the catalyst surface. Furthermore regeneration experiments were carried out with the catalyst showing the highest long-term stability. The results indicated the possibility to subsequently regenerate this catalyst at least five times without an observable loss of long-term stability. The regeneration procedure has to include a thermal treatment in a steam–air-mixture as well as an after treatment in hydrogen at not less than 120°C. Acknowledgement The authors thank K. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of acetylene is one process to remove traces of acetylene from steam cracker cuts during the production of ethylene. Current disadvantages of commercially used Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts applied in the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation are relative short cycle time (fast deactivation) caused by green oil formation and deposition of coke. Long-term tests were performed in a laboratory reactor under typical industrial conditions to investigate the deactivation of those catalysts. It was found that the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalyst with the highest long-term stability contains a Ag/Pd-ratio in the bulk of 0.41 and the lowest concentration of silver. This low silver amount causes a higher dilution of the palladium surface area than the higher silver amount within the investigated catalysts. This was indicated by CO chemisorption experiments, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron probe micro analysis (EPMA), X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and through the investigation of hydrocarbons deposited on the catalyst surface. The same catalyst sample was subsequently regenerated and tested in the laboratory reactor with respect to its long-term stability. The regenerated samples have the same long-term stability as the fresh sample if the regeneration procedure includes a hydrogen treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Performance and regeneration studies of Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene
